If you return early to Sol and you are not desperate to do so, ex: your hull is well enough to last, you have lots of o2 etc. this is reportable and will likely get a "return to Sol early" sanction. You are not to be returning early or suiciding for these jumps, you will net points.

Hi everyone!

I know a few people have been talking about doing something like this, a lot of people think its a good idea and some people are opposed, but hear me out! What I'm proposing, the Massive Mush Move is to Mush, what the Mega meta Jump is to Die2Nite. I will try and organize it if there is enough interest, so please use this thread to voice your opinions, whether you can't wait to take part, or if you think I'm wasting my time for whatever reason, please let me know here!

So here's the plan; Every month, let's say the first Saturday of every month, everyone who wants to join an active ship gets together on an IRC room, then we all hit the "start ship button" at pretty much the same time. And that's it! This would greatly increase the chances of landing in a ship full of active people who actually want to play, and who will log in regularly.

For this to work properly, I have outlined these basic rules, to make sure that this will leave a positive impression on the game and its community:
Everyone is welcome! That's right, invite any who enjoys playing mush, so long as they are willing to log in at least once a day, then spread the word and get them to join!
No side-swapping; Obvisouly normal game rules apply, but I just wanted to re-iterate this point, so even if you have been waiting for ages for a decent ship that you want to make go far, then you go and roll mush when you join the MMM ship, you HAVE to play as mush. This jump is for active people who want a challanging mush opponent, not necessarily a long-lasting ship.
Complete anonimity; Again, normal game rules apply, so don't reveal your name, or anyone else's, or go onto the forum and talk about what is going on in a ship in progress. If someone knows who you are they can 'cheat' the system and use this information to find out wether you are mush or not.
Every month! If this is to be a success it needs to be regular; something for everyone to look forward to. Some people have suggested it be bi-weekly, but monthly seems best to me: plenty of time for a long lasting ship to come to an end and still time to join a few less-active ships where people will be able to meet new active players and spread the word about the next MMM!

I'm going to go on a little bit of a counter-rant now, since I've heard people say "Oh just wait for castings" or "if all the experienced players are in ships on their own, who is to teach the new recruits?". Well, yes, they are both valid points, but the flip-side of the second argument is, that if that the new players who join, just end up in ship after ship of inactives, they will never get interested in this game, and you can say to them "wait until castings come out." but people who have never played the french Mush have no idea what the castings are. And if that newbie should ask "what are they and when are they coming out?" Well, I for one do not know, why would they bother waiting around in a game they don't enjoy for something that might not come out for several months? At least if you find an active player on a ship full of actives you can say with confidence "Wait until the first Saturday of December! MMM will get real interesting ships forming!" There's a chance that maybe someone who has the spare time to play this game, might just wait around to see what it really has in store. And this game will really start to fall apart if the experienced players start to quit if they can't get into a decent ship and their gold days are slowly draining away. So for the time being, everyone can join the ships full of newbs and inactives, find the few who are likely to want to continue to play, train them up, then, when its time, we can all enjoy Mush as its best!

So what do you think? Good idea? Waste of time? Let me know. If enough people (will need at least 30 interested) join in then I will organize an IRC room, then I'll set a date that works for everyone and we can all start getting excited about this game again!
-Abs out.

On november 8, 2013
Absydian

I'm glad so many people are replying to this topic, thanks for taking the time to do so!

Since posting this last night I'd like to straighten out a few things that have arisen since then:
First; Yes, EVERYONE is welcome. Bronze silver or gold, complete newbie or seasoned veteran from he french server, anyone who promises to log in at least once a day will be gladly accepted into the fold and can become part of the amazing community who follow this epic game.

Secondly, I think monthly is frequent enough. Some players have expressed concern that if there are frequent ships full of experts then there will be no one in the other ships helping the new players get to grips with this complicated game. Also, frequent ships will be far too tempting for players to start committing suicide. I do not want this event to start a epidemic of suicides. This kind of thing is already rife in Die2Nite and with a crew of only 16, suicides will have a much greater effect on those left behind on mush ships. For this thing to really work I think we need a decent balance of MMM ships and "normal" ships, so that people can spread the word to other people they meet on ships who don't read so much of the forum.

Thirdly, the date for the first jump (or move, or whatever) is currently set at the 7th December. No one has complained about this, but Rumata has suggested that a weekday might work better. Please can we turn the train of discussion to the date tat people would prefer? Once we have it set we can really start to advertise this to the crews we find ourselves with in the run-up to the jumpmovestepfallleapprance.

Once again, thanks for the support, keep the opinions coming; this is for the community so every reply matters!
-Abs

Or to quote one of my favorite fables:

The North Wind boasted of great strength. The Sun argued that there was great power in kindess.

"We shall have a contest," said the Sun.

Far below, a man traveled a winding road. He was wearing a warm winter coat.

"As a test of strength," said the Sun, "Let us see which of us can take the coat off of that man."

"It will be quite simple for me to force him to remove his coat," bragged the Wind.

The Wind blew so hard, the birds clung to the trees. The world was filled with dust and leaves. But the harder the wind blew down the road, the tighter the shivering man clung to his coat.

Then, the Sun came out from behind a cloud. Sun warmed the air and the frosty ground. The man on the road unbuttoned his coat.

The sun grew slowly brighter and brighter.

Soon the man felt so hot, he took off his coat and sat down in a shady spot.

"How did you do that?" said the Wind.

"It was easy," said the Sun, "I lit the day. Through kindness I got my way."

vidginexcuse me, what did you mean about "the weekly Mushday"? I hear about it for first time.

Sunday = Mushday
"Mushday": every sunday, in theory, at cycle 1, you jump into a ship, and everyone doing that should generate ships with fairly active people (as far as I understand it). I mean cycle 1 because I'm not sure how does it work with time zones (i.e.: in my case, cycle 1 happens at 9PM). So, if you pick a new ship to start, there's a fair chance that you end up in ships with other people looking for the same.
TL, DR: It's a weekly MMM for those who don't want to wait until next month

On february 1, 2014
Mokkero

Well, being mush isn't supposed to be easy, and is obviously a lot harder on a really active ship, but don't give up. Do your character's job well, do only sneaky stuff and play mind games. Refuse those stupid 'voluntary' tests, and if some one kills you for it, they're an idiot. Lots of people will also try to count your AP and actions, so make sure to think of excuses in advance for that.

Have a back up plan on what to do if you do get caught as well (don't do lame stuff though, like outing your partner to get the serum) - depending on your job you might be able to survive long and/or cause massive damage before you're eliminated. And if manage to survive long enough, maybe you'll get caught but instead of killed, you'll get the serum.

In any case, try to remember that mush are really important for the enjoyment of non-mush players as well, so try to take some joy out of being a part of the game, not just out of playing it - think of it like playing a healer, support or tank in an MMO.

[6795384]

Coming back to this: True. T'is not against the rules, you will be killed and start in a new ship. Hooray. But don't think for even a moment that you are NOT damaging that ship. The MUSH hunt is where the social elements really shine, where the most interesting and emotional parts of the game happen. A hunter hunted by hunters of man is, after all, the most dangerous game

So, to conclude, I really hope you will play as a human. Not for you, but for the crew from whom you would be stealing the fun otherwise...

On february 5, 2014
Sagittaeri

By the way, I'm one of the few people who track AP by following the raw logs. It's not as powerful as everyone seem to think it is. These are the reasons:

1. It takes TOO much time to track a single person's AP. So, I only track the suspicious ones. If we have too many suspicious ones, I might not even track them. Usually, I only can track 1 person per day while still having fun with the game, so I stick to that.

2. It takes a lot of APs to track other people APs. This is because you have to be ready to run around the ship and inspect room logs and examing equipments to make sure you don't miss anything.

3. A lot of people just forget to tell anyone they've relayed, or how many times they've worked on something consecutively. So, mush can easily hide their APs that way.

4. There are a LOT of ways you can mask your AP loss, at least at for most characters. Paola for example has her NERON version upgrades which has a large degree of chance in it.

5. There are so many variables to affect one's APs, including each person's human/mush skills, personal traits, what they may have saved up before, real life intervention (i.e. going offline for longer than expected and letting AP overflow), etc, that it's easy to make a human error.

So, while AP tracking is a good technique an investigative Eleesha should use, it doesn't mean the Mush has no chance. I'm actually hoping to one day become mush on one of the MMM ships to see how many days I can last for.

Vince

Yeah... you cannot stop people from doing MMM. Even if announcing it would be frobidden on these forums (which would be stupid) they would find other ways. - And, as always, putting restrictions on a symptom does not solve the problem.


An actual solution could be to have two or three different types of ships you can select when jumping, where higher tiers require a certain amount of XP gained / spent to unlock. (And only 1 of each filling at a time, so it won't take too long.)

For example, first time players will be put on an "easy" ship, which has a lower difficulty (at the expense of some glory) to make up for the higher number of inactives. Here the Mush will be newbies and more likely to give themselves away, but so are the humans which makes them less likely to notice.

Once you have, say, 50 xp, there could be "regular" ships for people who just like to play, and finally "hardcore" ships unlocked at 250 xp or such, for those players who want to number crunch and min/max everything to shoot for the highest scores. Maybe even have those for Gold/Silver only.

One nice side effect of this would be that banned players cannot just use a new email and continue being idiots on regular ships for a week.

And of course, people who want to teach others how to play are always free to join the tutorial ships.
Doing this as someone who already unlocked hardcore could even come with mild moderation rights, like the ability to suggest a preemptive ban / suppress certain actions of griefers even before the ship has ended.

[7930108]

I have been playing only random ships since a relatively early MMM2 return (no mushday, no MMM3), and I've met quite a few really good players on these ships. Research isn't powered through immediately, you don't get the exact projects you want, rations get wasted, you miss a few bases, there's a little more chaos... but I actually don't think those are really bad things. There is tension, there is actual danger that your ship could get taken down if the mush are clever enough. Instead of mindlessly doing your character's job and meticulously reporting your AP, you have to shirk some duties and participate in the mush hunt. Overall it's a lot more fun.

I'm convinced more and more people will get sick of having no challenge from the mush and then moving in hive-mind lockstep for 20 days. If a good number of people just voluntarily skip some of the MMMs, we'll have more in the random ship pool. I'm not even convinced it's a problem as-is, though. If you're looking for a marathon/Eden experience you're probably going to be disappointed most of the time, although I did have a recent random ship that easily cruised to the end of D11 until a quick succession of bad events convinced us to return. If you're looking for a fair fight and (if you survive) a struggle just to get back to Sol, you'll be happy. This is what I think mush is supposed to be.

On march 1, 2014
pkeod

If you join exactly at countdown you run the risks of joining a ship with half non-MMM players, which can be what some people want. If you wait a few minutes, but not too long, you'll probably be on a ship exclusively of MMM players. If you wait too long you'll be on the tail end and might have to wait a while for randoms to fill up the last MMM ship.
